ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MR TOOK LENG HOW

(Slipping out of Singapore undetected)

1. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Home Affairs how Took Leng

Column: 1157

How could have slipped out of Singapore undetected and whether this implies that there is some lapse in border control that has to be tightened.

2. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what are the causes which enabled Mr Took Leng How, whose passport has been impounded by the police, to slip out of Singapore despite the tightened security checks at our borders; (b) whether there are any other unreported cases of people who managed to slip in and out of our CIQ checkpoints successfully; and (c) whether there are any audit checks carried out to ensure that such incidents do not happen again.

The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 1 and 2 together as they are related?

Mr Speaker: Yes.

Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Police is currently concentrating their efforts on the investigation of the murder of Huang Na. Once investigations are completed and the case is tried in court, a clearer picture on many details, including how he left Singapore will be known. For now, we should let Police carry out its investigations.

Sir, let me assure the House that we treat the security at our checkpoints seriously. Since September 2001, security checks at all our checkpoints have been stepped up. These efforts have paid off by deterring people from sneaking in or out through our checkpoints. The Home Team arrested 81 illegal immigrants trying to enter Singapore through the land and sea checkpoints in 2003, a decline of some45% compared to the 147 arrested in 2002. 154 immigration offenders were

Column: 1158

arrested trying to depart Singapore from the land and sea checkpoints in 2003, a decline of some18% compared to 187 arrested in 2002.

Sir, to ensure that the checks at the checkpoints are robust, Police and the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) regularly carry out intrusion tests to critically assess and test the security performance of our checkpoints. After Action Reviews are then conducted to draw learning points for improvement.

Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): I would like to ask the Minister whether the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority was alerted to the fact that Took was actually called up by the Police to assist with the investigations of the case.

Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, like I have said, the case is still being investigated and the case will come before the courts.It is better for that process to be completed before we discuss any details.

Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, has the Ministry been monitoring the snakeheads operating in Singapore who are ferrying people in and out of Singapore illegally?

Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, as Mr Chia knows, we are mindful that we have to target snakeheads, not only illegal immigrant offenders. Where possible, we also try to smash syndicates, as recently happened in a case, not in Singapore, which involved a Malaysian in Malaysia.With close cooperation, we were able to smash that syndicate. So, definitely, this is one of the points that ICA and Police will look at.

Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, I note the Minister's reply that investigations are still underway. But regardless of this, because of the

Column: 1159

possibility of his having escaped through the border, was there any tightening of border control measures after this incident?

Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, as the House knows, we take our border security seriously. And, indeed, particularly after September 11, many measures have been implemented to tighten our borders. As of now, following our assessment, whatever gaps that may appear, arising from Police investigations, have been closed up.

Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, sinceborder security has now been tightened,how can anybody actually manage to sneak out of Singapore?

Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, we are entering into the realm of the details which, I think, we should leaveaside until after investigations are completed and the case is set in court.

RECORDS OF TRAFFIC OFFENDERS

The following Question stood in the name of Mr Zainudin Nordin -

3. To ask the Minister for Home Affairs (a) how long are the records of traffic offenders (i) who have not paid their fines and (ii) who are wanted under an arrest warrant stored in his Ministry's databank; and (b) how is it possible that some traffic offenders who surrendered themselves on an arrest warrant and later paid up all their fines, can still be served subsequently with outstanding arrest warrants.

Mr Ahmad Khalis Bin Abdul Ghani (Hong Kah): Question No. 3, Sir.

Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, any traffic offender who fails to pay a composition fine by the expiry date, as reflected in the Notice of Traffic Offence, will be issued a notice to attend court to answer to the

Column: 1160

charge preferred against him. If he fails to show up in court, a warrant of arrest will then be issued against him. The records of these outstanding fines and warrants are kept by the Traffic Police until they are dealt with.

When a traffic offender surrenders himself to the Traffic Police, the Traffic Police will ensure that all his other outstanding traffic offences are dealt with concurrently. This is so that he will not be unduly inconvenienced. Nonetheless, it is possible that an offender who has paid up his fine for a traffic offence can still be issued a warrant of arrest subsequently. Let me explain.

Take the case of a traffic offender who fails to pay the composition fine by the expiry date and also fails to attend court to answer the charge. The court will then issue a warrant of arrest against him. He subsequently surrenders himself to the Traffic Police and submits an appeal. The Traffic Police, in consultation with the Attorney General's Chambers, decides to re-offer him the option of compounding his traffic offence by paying a fine, which he does. In this case, even though the offender has already paid the composition fine for his traffic offence, he will still be required to attend court to show cause as to why he failed to attend court in the first place. If he fails again to turn up in court, another warrant of arrest will be issued against him.

IT EDUCATION

The following Question stood in the name of Mr Zainudin Nordin -

4. To ask the Minister for Education with the investments and effort to introduce IT, eLearning and early exposure of our students to computers and software in schools (a) what are the improvements in education and learning; (b) what are the key progresses of these

Column: 1161

initiatives; and (c) whether his Ministry allows students to leverage on their IT skills for the key examinations like the GCE 'N', GCE 'O' and GCE 'A'.

Mr Ahmad Khalis Bin Abdul Ghani: Question No. 4, Sir.

The Minister of State for Education (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (for the Minister for Education): Sir, IT is a key enabler for Singapore to remain competitive and meet the challenges of the knowledge-driven future. MOE launched the first IT Masterplan in education in 1997 to put in place the necessary infrastructure to enable our schools to leverage on IT to enhance the learning experience of and to better prepare our students for the future.

With the successful implementation of the first IT Masterplan, all our schools are now connected to the Internet and ready for other IT enabled learning. All our teachers have also at least acquired the necessary basic knowledge and skills to integrate IT into the curriculum.

The IT-enabled school environment is conducive for our students to participate in active learning. With the use of IT, our students are now able to go beyond the four walls of their classrooms.For example, we have students in 20 schools who were involved in a project that tackled the problem of dengue fever. This project required our students to collaborate with a specialist from Vietnam as well as our Ministry of the Environment. They analysed data, evaluated information and created knowledge using personal digital devices as well as the Global Positioning System (GPS).

Many of our students have acquired not only basic digital literacy but sophisticated IT skills like web publishing, video-creation and computer programming. Many of them have also excelled in local and international

Column: 1162

competitions like ThinkQuest International and International Olympiad in Informatics. In fact, they are better than us adults in many instances.

With the launch of the second ITMasterplan in Education, we are beginning to see a variety of school-initiated IT-based programmes to support niche areas in the schools such as in inquiry-based learning and life-sciences. MOE, schools, industry partners, and Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) are collaborating on experimental projects to push the frontiers of innovative ways of using IT for teaching and learning. One example is the use of knowledge forum software, an online discussion forum, to bring about engaged learning for our students.

On assessment, students make use of their IT skills in the coursework and practical components of the N-level Computer Applications examination. Students also leverage on their IT skills for research, processing of data, presentation and collaboration in Project Work at A-level. In the A-level Computing examinations, studentsalso make use of application software for computer-aided designs, database management and web publishing in the coursework component of the examination. MOE will continue to explore new ways of using IT in assessment.

Mr Ahmad Khalis Bin Abdul Ghani: Sir, I am pleased to note that many of our children have benefited from and do excel in the use of IT. But I am sure the Minister would agree with me that a large number of children, maybe due to financial reasons, do not have an IT-friendly atmosphere at home and therefore may be left behind, compared to their classmates who have computers at home and attend computer enrichment classes. Does the Minister observe that there is a widening IT divide among our children? And if there is such a growing divide, what is the Ministry's policy on

Column: 1163

this? Whatactions does the Ministry intend to take?

Mr Chan Soo Sen: That is why the Ministry introduces IT in a relatively cautious manner. We only introduce IT that has good education application. Also, thetechnology introduced has got to be mature and also affordable. For students who are unable to afford their own computers,wearrange for them to make use of the facilities in school, for example, in a computer laboratory.

We also have certain schools which introduced their ownIT projects. For example, Crescent Girls' School introduced IT teaching programme using the tablet PC.In this particular case,the schoolhadconsulted all stakeholders, especiallythe parents. Nearly allagreed tobuytablet PCs for their children. In the case of the few who were unable to afford, the school was able toarrange for the tablet PCs to be loaned to them. So the school went all outto make sure that students do not lose out because they were unableto afford the PCs.So just to assure the Member that affordability and availability of computers weretaken into consideration before IT projects were introduced.

Mdm Ho Geok Choo: I would like to ask the Minister whether the Ministry will consider making such facilities accessible at community clubs and community centres, so that on a more macro level we can better reach out to students who are living within the community.

Mr Chan Soo Sen: Community centres and community clubsare not under the care of the Ministry of Education. But suffice it to say, we also have other voluntary organisations, like the community self-help groups, MENDAKI, CDAC,SINDA as well asthe Eurasian Association, which do have schemesto allow the students to have access to

Column: 1164

computers. Theyinvolve many volunteers to help, for example, to service old computers. Computers made available through such channels, pluscomputer facilities available in schools have,for the time being, beenadequate to caterto our students.

Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, having all these efforts in IT, do we seea need for our students to be allowed to use the skills that they have acquired for important examinations? And if that is the case, is there any situation where students are not allowed to use the skills for examinations, like presentations or whatever?

Mr Chan Soo Sen: If we are introducing the use of computer in an examination, we must, firstly,make sure that all students have access to computer at that examination.There isthis issue of IT divide between the students who have and whodo not have a computer. So,for the time being, the use of computer in examinations is confinedto computer-related subjects, like the subjects that I have listed during my oralanswer just now. To the extent thatcomputer becomes more accessible and more affordable, there will be a wider use of computer in examinations.


Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Could I ask the Minister whether the Ministry has any scheme of identifying children who would appreciate a computer at home and looking for the means to help them get that computer so that we bring more people on to the same level to level the playing field?

Mr Chan Soo Sen: As I said, if the students do not have a computer at home,there are other channels to help them, such as the community self-help groups.Our schoolshave also been helping students to getin touch with the

Column: 1165

various channels. In certain instances, the schools may approach some charitable organisations to make available additional resources. All these are being done.

Ms Braema Mathiaparanam: Do we know the number of school children who may not possess a home computer? Is there any study done in this area? Are schools opening up their school laboratories so that, after school hours and on weekends, children who need to do their homework or browse through the Net to do whatever research, they are made available to them?

Mr Chan Soo Sen: Opening of computer laboratories in schools after school hours or during weekends are decisions that can be taken by the schools. The Ministry does not have a directive to direct the schools to open their computer facilitiesat certain hours. But I am confident that if it is for the good of the students, the schools will make those facilities available.

As for the study thatthe Memberasked for,I do not have the information with me. But we canget certain indications on the penetration rate of IT in families. I think yesterday, during the Second Reading of one of the Bills,it was mentioned thatmore than half of our families now have access to Internet. So if thereis access to Internet,they must have access to computers. But I think these are not the people that she is concerned about. She is more concerned about the people who are really not able to afford having a computer at home for the use of their children. As I have said earlier, there are various groups who have schemesthat try to cater to the needs of these children. And as far as I know, the provision currently is adequate.

Mr Zainudin Nordin: Sir, I appreciate the concern about the digital divide. But

Column: 1166

at the same time, I am also concerned that with the kind of investment and the kind of money that we have beenputting into IT, whatis the level of achievement we expect from our students? If we want them to attaincertain IT skills and we want them to apply, how can MOE assistthe students to apply their skills that they have acquired in this training atimportant examinations, like GCE 'N', GCE 'O', and so forth? I would prefer for us to be able to level up than level down.

Mr Chan Soo Sen: Iwould acceptMr Zainudin's pointgenerally. But I would want to say that there are certain areas of assessment that we are actively exploring the possible use of IT. One of them is actually in the area of oral examination. Nowadays, there are computers which can recognise pronunciation and voices. A natural question iswhether suchcapabilities can be used to help in theassessment for oral examination, especially those relatively objective types of oral examination. I am not talking about, say, free flow conversation. Oral examinations involvingmultiple choice or reading from a fixed passage could conceivably be assessed by computer.This is one area that we are actively looking into.

I would also want to say that IT in teaching goes beyond just examinations. IT allows students to practise a certain skill repeatedly in order to improve. For example, students can do repeated practice ofmathematics, or repeated practiceof reading ofpassages. A computer is actuallyvery patient. You can make the same mistake many times. The computerswill patientlycorrect it for you.These features are already available in our computer laboratories.Hence,the use of IT in education is manifold. It goes beyond assessment. And I think our children are benefiting from these capabilities.

MINISTRY OF MANPOWER

(Implementation of four-day work week and job sharing)

5. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Manpower (a) if he will update the House on the newly announced four-day work week and job sharing that his Ministry has implemented in its own set up; and (b) what are some of the guidelines that have been drawn up to assist corporations to better identify operations that can support a four-day work week.

The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Minister for Manpower):My Ministry is not promoting a 4-day work week, as wrongly headlined in a recent press report. We have clarified this to the newspaper. What MOM has put in place are flexible work options, such as flexi-time, telecommuting, working from home, job sharing and part-time employment.

Like many other companies with flexi-time, some MOM officers start earlier or later than the official starting time of 8.30 am. For other options like telecommuting and part-time work, approvals are granted selectively for limited periods and when the performance and productivity of the officer and his or her division are not compromised. Currently,about 1,080 staff in MOM, 9 or 0.8%, are on these schemes, and they aretypically mothers.

Mdm Ho Geok Choo: In view of the competitive environment that we are encouraging in Singapore and the recent calls for flexibility in our work patterns, will the Ministry actually be working out some schemes to provide some guidelines on how flexible working hours or flexible work week can actually be implemented in organisations?

Mr Hawazi Daipi: Flexible work arrangement is practised widely in the

Column: 1168

industry. The Ministry would not want to prescribe a certain formula for different industries and companies to subscribe to. What we would like to see is arrangement that would be mutually beneficial to both the employees as well as the employers. So as long as the rights of the workers and the interests of the companies, as a whole, are well protected and taken care of, we would encourage different kinds of flexi arrangements.

SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURS AND ENTERPRISE

6. Miss Penny Low asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports, givenhis Ministry's aspiration to promote social entrepreneurship in Singapore, (a) what progress has Singapore made; (b) what help is given to people who want to start up social enterprises; and (c) whatis the profile of the social entrepreneurs and enterprise in Singapore, especially those set up in the last two years.

The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon) (for the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports):Mr Speaker, Sir, Miss Penny Low has asked about Singapore's progress in promoting social enterprises. First of all, let me define social enterprises as ventures that use business practices to achieve a social mission. Profits earnedare re-invested in social causes, rather than to maximise the owners' gains. Some local examples would be the "Mister Clean" cleaning service that employs ex-offenders, and the airline headset recycling service offered toSIA, which employs the intellectually disabled.

Social enterprises like these are not yet widespread in Singapore, but they have slowly gained some ground.

MCYS wants to encourage the growth of more social enterprises. This is because the revenue from social

Column: 1169

enterprises would enable social service agencies to be more self-reliant, and less dependent on donations to fund their social causes.With this additional source of fund,social service agencies can do even more than what their donations could allow them to. As a positive spin-off, social enterprises can also create jobs for groups who would normally face difficulty in finding meaningful employment.

Those who want to start social enterprises may be able to get seed capital through my Ministry's Social Enterprise Fund (SEF), which started in March 2003. The objective of theSEF is to encourage the social service sector to look at possible business projectsas another avenue for raising funds.Over the longer term, we hope that theSEF will help the social service sector to be more self-reliant, financially sustainable and innovative.

To date, about $3.4 million has been awarded from the Social Enterprise Fund to support 33 projects. From these approved projects, 23 have started operations.

64% of the projects are started by Voluntary Welfare Organisations (VWOs), with the remainder mostly by businessmen supporting a social cause. Many of the VWO-driven projects involve partnership or guidance from the private sector.

One example is Killiney Kopitiam, which helped Teen Challenge to set up a Killiney Kopitiam franchise, with a waiver ofits franchise fee. Profits from this venture are used to further Teen Challenge's social missionin re-integrating ex-drug addicts.

Another example is apublic sector-privatesector collaboration between

Column: 1170

Bizlink, a non-profit organisation providing job-matching services for the disabled, and Trusted Hub, a member of the Singapore Technologies Group. They have set up a data entry centre, which provides job opportunities for the disabled.

Besides giving funding support, MCYSassists start-up social enterprises by linking them with potential mentors, such as experienced businessmen and established social enterprises.

We also build awareness of this concept of social enterprise through public forums and the media. MCYS has promoted the Social Enterprise Fund to social service agencies under the National Council of Social Services, National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre, NUS, SMU and Singapore International Foundation, and so on.

Miss Penny Low asked about the profile of social entrepreneurs and social enterprises in Singapore. The Ministry does not have comprehensive data on this. But based on the projects that we have funded, social enterprises span across various businesses, including foodand beverage, car polishing services, cleaning services and data entry services, and so on. The beneficiaries include ex-drug addicts, ex-offenders, the disabled, the elderly, delinquent youths and those who are chronically unemployed.

Mr Speaker, Sir, while the status of social enterprises has grown, it is still in its infancy. Besides MCYS, the community can also help develop social enterprises in various ways; companies can consider social enterprises as potential business partners, while businessmen can share their expertise, resources and connections. So we hope that we will have a "many helping hands" approach to improve supportforthis socialmission in the future.

Column: 1171

Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Sir, I am very happy to hear the Minister of State detailing the social enterprises that started in the last two years or so. I am also aware that wehave still got a long way to go, in terms of learning the best practices of running social enterprises. Has there been any effort on the part of MCYS to come out with some guidelines or to liaise with even international social enterprises and run even MTI-like programmes, like Blue Sky, to link up the aspiring social entrepreneurs and the existing social entrepreneurs?

Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Miss Penny Low has given a very good suggestion. Like I just mentioned,we started last year, in March 2003, and now we have 33 projects. So we do havecompanies, especially some GLCs and voluntary groups that are tryingto work together. Lately,the grassroots organisations, likethe Pasir Ris grassroots leaders, have also started the "Aunty Clubs" tohelp some of the unemployed aunties. So I think social enterprises cover a very wide spectrum. The most important point is that, ultimately, whatever we do, we should remember these three objectives. One,the mission should be very clear,ie, whatever profits we have should be ploughed back to support the social mission.Second, the project should be commercially viable and sustainable. And,ofcourse,third,


we examine theleadership, ie, dowe have a team of people, the drivers, who are prepared to help them to make sure that these businesses aresuccessful? If these threecriteria are met, please come to the Ministry and we will look into their applications.

Mdm Ho Geok Choo: I would like to ask the Minister whether there is a difference between a VWO cooperative and a social enterprise. What are the main differences? In other words, can the business operations of a VWO cooperative

Column: 1172

in a way be classified as the business operations of a social enterprise?

Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Based on the criteria, an applicant should be a registered body in Singapore. This can include a company limited by guarantee, a society,cooperative or charitable institution. But the business partner can help the VWO to start a social enterprise.

Miss Penny Low: Would the Minister also consider publishing a list of contacts of companies or corporations in Singapore which are interested to help out in social enterprises?

Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: We will look into the various publicity channels.I think it is quite a good suggestion that maybe we should slowly compile a more comprehensive list of contacts to help those who are interested to do so.
